2. A 4-year-old female presented to the emergency department with high-grade fevers, progressive weakness, and persistent cough lasting two weeks. The parents reported her having unusually light-colored eyebrows and scalp hair since birth, along with frequent infections since infancy. On examination, the child exhibited silvery-gray hair, hypopigmented skin patches, and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Neurologic evaluation revealed ataxia and poor coordination. Laboratory studies showed pancytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and increased ferritin levels. A peripheral blood smear indicated hemophagocytosis, raising concern for macrophage activation syndrome. Hair microscopy demonstrated characteristic large, uneven melanin clumps consistent with Griscelli Syndrome. Genetic analysis identified mutations in the MYO5A gene, confirming a diagnosis of Griscelli Syndrome type 1 with associated neurologic involvement.
